body.p:
Your letter of the 15th
inst. came safely to hand on Saturday
while I was hurrying to get off several
orders and to get out of town by a late
evening train. So it was not in my power
to do more than read it and lay it by for
attention this morning.

Your change of base from Newport
to Newark is a wise one I think.

While it is true as you say that
an agent has been in Newark, if I have
been rightly informed he accomplished
nothing. Indeed it can hardly be said that
he made an effort. This I learned from
the agent himself and thereto
Rev. Mr. Morris gave me the same
idea. The agent went under Porter Coates'
auspices, not mine. I shall be very
happy to present a copy to Rev. Morris +
also a copy or two to leading papers.
I will look over my list and see if the
papers they have been furnished - if they
have I do not want them to have duplicate
copies.

On Saturday evening I went up
to Burlington to see Aunt Viney + and
passed a short visit with them most
pleasantly.

Mr Jones is a little better
but fast in bed yet and I think him
in a precarious condition. He seems to
feel conscious of the importance of making
peace with his god ere he departs
and I hope and trust he may.

I was aware that Duieger
entertained a good opinion of Harvey’s
ability to push the U.G.R.R. but as yet
he has not set the world on fire. “Too many
books,” I think with you, is the cause
of failure with too many agents - and
I am therefore opposed to giving agencies
to persons thus encumbered.

We are all pretty well this
morning and the rain is coming down
in good earnest.
